AI Chatbot Project Charter

Project Charter: AI Customer Service Chatbot

Executive Summary

Project Name: RetailFlow AI Customer Service Chatbot Pilot
Budget: AUD $150,000
Timeline: 6 months (24 weeks)
Sponsor: Emma Rodriguez, CEO
Project Manager: External Consultant (You)

Business Case

Problem Statement

RetailFlow’s customer service is in crisis: - Email response times: 26 hours (Target: < 4 hours) - Customer satisfaction: 68% (Target: 78%) - Annual cost: AUD $2.4M for customer service operations - Staff turnover: 35% annually in customer service

Proposed Solution

Implement an AI-powered chatbot to handle common customer inquiries, providing: - 24/7 availability - Instant response times - Consistent quality - Cost reduction

Expected Benefits

  • Cost Savings: AUD $600K annually (25% reduction)
  • CSAT Improvement: +10 percentage points
  • Response Time: < 2 seconds for common queries
  • Staff Productivity: 40% increase in human agent efficiency

Project Scope

In Scope

  1. Chatbot Development: AI-powered customer service bot
  2. Knowledge Base: Product information, policies, procedures
  3. Integration: Email system, CRM, website
  4. Training: Staff handover procedures and escalation protocols
  5. Testing: 3-month pilot with 20% of customer inquiries
  6. Analytics: Performance metrics and ROI tracking

Out of Scope

  1. Voice Assistant: Not included in initial pilot
  2. Social Media Integration: Future phase consideration
  3. Complete Automation: Human agents remain essential
  4. Multi-language: English only for pilot
  5. Advanced AI: No predictive capabilities in phase 1

Success Metrics

Primary KPIs

Metric Current Target (6 months) Measurement
Email Response Time 26 hours < 4 hours System tracking
Customer Satisfaction 68% 78% Post-interaction surveys
Cost per Inquiry AUD $12 AUD $8 Financial analysis
First Contact Resolution 45% 65% System metrics

Secondary KPIs

  • Chatbot Containment Rate: 60% of inquiries resolved without human escalation
  • Staff Satisfaction: Improve from 5.2 to 7.0/10
  • Training Time: Reduce new hire training by 30%
  • Error Rate: < 5% incorrect responses

Timeline & Phases

Phase 1: Discovery & Planning (Weeks 1-4)

  • Requirements gathering
  • Vendor selection
  • Technical architecture design
  • Risk assessment

Phase 2: Development (Weeks 5-12)

  • Chatbot development
  • Knowledge base creation
  • Integration setup
  • Internal testing

Phase 3: Pilot Launch (Weeks 13-16)

  • 20% customer volume
  • Human oversight
  • Performance monitoring
  • Feedback collection

Phase 4: Optimization (Weeks 17-20)

  • Performance tuning
  • Additional training
  • Process refinement
  • Scale preparation

Phase 5: Evaluation (Weeks 21-24)

  • Full ROI analysis
  • Go/No-Go decision
  • Rollout planning
  • Lessons learned

Budget Breakdown

Category Amount Notes
Technology/Software AUD $60,000 Chatbot platform, licenses
Implementation AUD $45,000 Development, integration
Training & Change Management AUD $25,000 Staff training, communication
Contingency AUD $20,000 15% of total budget
Total AUD $150,000

Risk Management

High Risks

  1. Technology Failure: Chatbot doesn’t perform as expected
    • Mitigation: Thorough testing, vendor guarantees
  2. Customer Rejection: Customers prefer human interaction
    • Mitigation: Gradual rollout, opt-out options
  3. Staff Resistance: Employees feel threatened
    • Mitigation: Inclusive planning, retraining programs

Medium Risks

  1. Integration Issues: Technical problems with existing systems
  2. Budget Overrun: Unexpected costs during implementation
  3. Timeline Delays: Vendor or internal delays

Low Risks

  1. Security Concerns: Data privacy issues
  2. Regulatory Compliance: Legal or regulatory requirements
  3. Vendor Dependence: Over-reliance on single provider

Stakeholder Map

Key Stakeholders

  • Executive Team: Emma Rodriguez (CEO), David Chen (CFO)
  • Project Team: Marcus Kim (CIO), Sarah Chen (Customer Service)
  • End Users: Customer service agents, customers
  • Technical Team: Dr. Priya Sharma (Data Science), Rajesh Patel (Security)

Communication Plan

  • Weekly: Project team status updates
  • Bi-weekly: Executive steering committee
  • Monthly: All-hands project updates
  • Ad-hoc: Issue escalation and decisions

Governance

Decision Making

  • Budget Decisions: CEO and CFO approval
  • Technical Decisions: CIO and Data Science lead
  • Operational Decisions: Customer Service Manager
  • Go/No-Go: Full executive committee

Success Criteria

Project considered successful if: 1. 3 of 4 primary KPIs met 2. ROI > 150% within 18 months 3. Customer and staff satisfaction > 7/10 4. No major security incidents
